<ce:figure id="f0005">

<ce:caption id="cn0250">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0105" view="all">(a) The coordination environment of Mn(II) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (b) 2D layer of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, viewed along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. (c) 1D layer of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, viewed along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis. (d) 3D net of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) The coordination environment of Mn(II) in 1. (b) 2D layer of 1, viewed along the b axis. (c) 1D layer of 1, viewed along the b axis. (d) 3D net of 1. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:

(b) 3D supramolecular structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> constructed by π⋯π stacking interactions. (c) 1D zigzag chain of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Six different coordination polymers based on a main dicarboxyl ligand and auxiliary ligands have been synthesized. According to the analyses of the various architectures, the ligands showed important effects on the constructions of final structures in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.<ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Six different coordination polymers based on a main dicarboxyl ligand and auxiliary ligands have been synthesized. According to the analyses of the various architectures, the ligands showed important effects on the constructions of final structures in complexes 1-6.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Complexes 1-6 was synthesized via hydrothermal methods.   ⋅ Crystal structures and thermal stability of complexes 1-6 have been described.   ⋅ Fluorescent properties and magnetic behavior of complexes 1-6 have been studied.   ⋅ Mixed ligands play important roles in the construction of complexes 1-6.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> was synthesized via hydrothermal methods.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Crystal structures and thermal stability of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> have been described.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Fluorescent properties and magnetic behavior of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> have been studied.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Mixed ligands play important roles in the construction of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st015">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Six coordination polymers, namely, Mn(dpd)(bpy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Co(dpd)(bpy) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Cu(dpd)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd)(bpy) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), Mn(dpd)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), Co(dpd)(phen)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), Co(dpd)(phen)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,4-diphenyl ether dicarboxylic acid, bpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′-bipyridine, phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) have been synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions by H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd, auxiliary ligands and different transition metal salts. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 3D (3,3)-connected framework which is connected by dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows 1D zigzag chain, which is further connected by hydrogen bonds to form a 3D supramolecular net. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is constructed from infinite 1D chains which are linked by dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand exhibiting a 2D supramolecular layer. Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is a mononuclear structure which is further self-assembled through hydrogen bonding and π···π stacking interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular structure. Complexes <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are 1D chains and further connected by hydrogen bonding and π⋯π stacking interactions to form a 3D supramolecular structure. These complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, infrared (IR), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, UV–Vis spectra and fluorescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> have been investigated. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> all show weak ferromagnetic behaviors.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Complexes 1-6 was synthesized via hydrothermal methods.

Crystal structures and thermal stability of complexes 1-6 have been described.

Fluorescent properties and magnetic behavior of complexes 1-6 have been studied.

Mixed ligands play important roles in the construction of complexes 1-6.

Abstract

Six coordination polymers, namely, Mn(dpd)(bpy)(H2O) (1), Co(dpd)(bpy) (2), Cu(dpd)(H2dpd)(bpy) (3), Mn(dpd)(phen)2(H2O) (4), Co(dpd)(phen)(H2O) (5), Co(dpd)(phen)(H2O) (6) (H2dpd=2,4-diphenyl ether dicarboxylic acid, bpy=2,2'-bipyridine, phen=1,10-phenanthroline) have been synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions by H2dpd, auxiliary ligands and different transition metal salts. Complex 1 is a 3D (3,3)-connected framework which is connected by dpd2- ligand. Complex 2 shows 1D zigzag chain, which is further connected by hydrogen bonds to form a 3D supramolecular net. Complex 3 is constructed from infinite 1D chains which are linked by dpd2- ligand exhibiting a 2D supramolecular layer. Complex 4 is a mononuclear structure which is further self-assembled through hydrogen bonding and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular structure. Complexes 5 and 6 are 1D chains and further connected by hydrogen bonding and π⋯π stacking interactions to form a 3D supramolecular structure. These complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, infrared (IR), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Furthermore, UV-Vis spectra and fluorescence properties of 1-6 have been investigated. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that complexes 2-6 all show weak ferromagnetic behaviors.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Metal–organic coordination polymers have attracted much attention in the field of crystal engineering, material, solid and coordination chemistry , which is owing to their intriguing architectures and promising applications in magnetism , catalysis  and optics . The self-assembly of different metal centers and organic linkers is one of the most efficient strategies for the construction of diverse structures and desired functionalities of coordination polymers . In this case, multidentate organic ligands containing O-donor or N-donor have been confirmed to play important roles in the construction of coordination polymers .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic coordination polymers have attracted much attention in the field of crystal engineering, material, solid and coordination chemistry , which is owing to their intriguing architectures and promising applications in magnetism , catalysis  and optics . The self-assembly of different metal centers and organic linkers is one of the most efficient strategies for the construction of diverse structures and desired functionalities of coordination polymers . In this case, multidentate organic ligands containing O-donor or N-donor have been confirmed to play important roles in the construction of coordination polymers .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The dicarboxyl groups can possess four potential coordination sites to adopt different coordination modes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>) and the –C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O groups can act as O-donors. It is well known that dicarboxylate ligand is a perfect candidate to form versatile coordination conformations from terminal monodentate to various modes to result in 0D cages, 1D chains, 2D grids and 3D porous frameworks . Furthermore, bpy and phen ligands containing N-donor are often used for constructing coordination polymers because of their chelating ability with the metal centers . They can also interact with the metal centers through π⋯π stacking interactions and act as hydrogen bond donors and acceptors to adjust to different structures of complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The dicarboxyl groups can possess four potential coordination sites to adopt different coordination modes ( ) and the -CO groups can act as O-donors. It is well known that dicarboxylate ligand is a perfect candidate to form versatile coordination conformations from terminal monodentate to various modes to result in 0D cages, 1D chains, 2D grids and 3D porous frameworks . Furthermore, bpy and phen ligands containing N-donor are often used for constructing coordination polymers because of their chelating ability with the metal centers . They can also interact with the metal centers through π⋯π stacking interactions and act as hydrogen bond donors and acceptors to adjust to different structures of complexes .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Hence the 2,4-diphenyl ether dicarboxylic acid and N-containing auxiliary ligands were used to synthesize six novel metal–organic coordination polymers, Mn(dpd)(bpy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), Co(dpd)(bpy) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Cu(dpd)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd)(bpy) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), Mn(dpd)(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), Co(dpd)(phen)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), Co(dpd)(phen)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>). These complexes are characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. UV–Vis spectra, fluorescent and magnetic properties of these complexes are also discussed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Hence the 2,4-diphenyl ether dicarboxylic acid and N-containing auxiliary ligands were used to synthesize six novel metal-organic coordination polymers, Mn(dpd)(bpy)(H2O) (1), Co(dpd)(bpy) (2), Cu(dpd)(H2dpd)(bpy) (3), Mn(dpd)(phen)2(H2O) (4), Co(dpd)(phen)(H2O) (5), Co(dpd)(phen)(H2O) (6). These complexes are characterized by elemental analysis, IR, TG, and single crystal X-ray diffraction. UV-Vis spectra, fluorescent and magnetic properties of these complexes are also discussed.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">All reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used as-purchased without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded (as KBr pressed pellets) in the range of 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a Nicolet 170SXFT-IR spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 instrument in nitrogen at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. The PXRD diagrams were collected by a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. Fluorescence spectra were measured by a Hitachi Model RF-5301 PC fluorescence spectrophotometer with a Xenon lamp light source. The magnetic measurements were performed on the Quantum Design SQUID MPMSXL-7 instruments in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used as-purchased without further purification. Elemental analysis for C, H and N were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded (as KBr pressed pellets) in the range of 400-4000cm-1 on a Nicolet 170SXFT-IR spectrometer. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were collected on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 instrument in nitrogen at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The PXRD diagrams were collected by a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. Fluorescence spectra were measured by a Hitachi Model RF-5301 PC fluorescence spectrophotometer with a Xenon lamp light source. The magnetic measurements were performed on the Quantum Design SQUID MPMSXL-7 instruments in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe in the temperature range of 2-300K.

After cooling to room temperature at a speed of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, yellow crystals of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained, washed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air (Yield: 42% based on Mn). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>MnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>: C, 59.39; H, 3.74, N, 5.77. Found: C, 59.29; H, 3.88; N, 5.72%. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complex 1 

A mixture of Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.2mmol, 0.0490g), H2dpd (0.2mmol, 0.0512g), bpy (0.2mmol, 0.0312g), 25% (C2H5)4NOH (mass fraction) aqueous solution (0.1ml) and H2O (5mL) was sealed in a 23mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 160°C for 3days. After cooling to room temperature at a speed of 10°C/h, yellow crystals of complex 1 were obtained, washed with H2O and dried in air (Yield: 42% based on Mn). Anal. Calc. for C24H18MnN2O6: C, 59.39; H, 3.74, N, 5.77. Found: C, 59.29; H, 3.88; N, 5.72%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3381 (s), 1590 (s), 1545 (s), 1479 (m), 1422(s), 1365 (m), 1243 (s), 1165 (m), 1102 (w), 1057 (w), 1032 (m), 1006 (w), 893 (m), 847 (m), 802 (w), 759 (s), 720 (w), 645 (w), 612 (w), 497(w).

elements.clean_text:
Single-crystal X-ray crystallography

Diffraction data for 1-6 were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer by graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Empirical absorption corrections were taken from sadabs . The space group was determined by using xprep . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares method using the shelxs-97 and shelxl-97 . Crystallographic data for complexes 1-6 were summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in , ESI. Hydrogen bonding interactions of 1-6 are given in , ESI.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st075">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st080">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> were obtained by hydrothermal reactions of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd, N-donor ligands and different transition metal salts. The changes of temperature and reactants ratios remarkably influence the final structures of the products. Different complexes or none were obtained while the temperatures were changed. In addition, several other molar ratios of the reactants (0.1:0.1:0.2, 0.2:0.2:0.1) have been tried before, but only the ratio of 0.2:0.2:0.2 succeeded to obtain the complexes. Auxiliary N-donor ligands and different coordination modes of dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand may also play important roles in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, and may be a feasible method to adopt different ligands to construct coordination polymers with targeted structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

Complexes 1-6 were obtained by hydrothermal reactions of H2dpd, N-donor ligands and different transition metal salts. The changes of temperature and reactants ratios remarkably influence the final structures of the products. Different complexes or none were obtained while the temperatures were changed. In addition, several other molar ratios of the reactants (0.1:0.1:0.2, 0.2:0.2:0.1) have been tried before, but only the ratio of 0.2:0.2:0.2 succeeded to obtain the complexes. Auxiliary N-donor ligands and different coordination modes of dpd2- ligand may also play important roles in complexes 1-6, and may be a feasible method to adopt different ligands to construct coordination polymers with targeted structures.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st085">Crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system <ce:italic>Cc</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) atom, one dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one bpy ligand and one water molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Mn(II) atom is placed in a distorted octahedron, which is completed by three oxygen atoms from three dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, two nitrogen atoms from one chelating bpy ligand and one water molecules. The Mn–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.121–2.227<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Mn–N bond lengths are 2.277 and 2.307<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand adopts a bidentate and monodentate–bridging mode, linking three independent Mn(II) atoms (a). Adjacent Mn(II) atoms are connected by dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into a 3D metal–organic framework. The Mn(II) atom and dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand can be simplified as 3-connected nodes. Thus, the whole framework can be considered as a (3,3)-connected net (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system Cc. The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one bpy ligand and one water molecule. As shown in  a, each Mn(II) atom is placed in a distorted octahedron, which is completed by three oxygen atoms from three dpd2- ligands, two nitrogen atoms from one chelating bpy ligand and one water molecules. The Mn-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.121-2.227Å, and the Mn-N bond lengths are 2.277 and 2.307Å. Each dpd2- ligand adopts a bidentate and monodentate-bridging mode, linking three independent Mn(II) atoms (a). Adjacent Mn(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into a 3D metal-organic framework. The Mn(II) atom and dpd2- ligand can be simplified as 3-connected nodes. Thus, the whole framework can be considered as a (3,3)-connected net (d).

<ce:section-title id="st090">Crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a zigzag 1D chain and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group of <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>21/<ce:italic>c.</ce:italic> In the asymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there are one Co(II) atom, one dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and one bpy ligand. The Co(II) atom is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two nitrogen atoms from one chelating bpy ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). The dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand adopts a chelating coordination mode to connect two Co(II) atoms (b), linking the Co(II) atoms into a zigzag 1D chain (c). The π⋯π stacking interactions of the nearly bpy ligands with the distances between 3.7059<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 3.8962<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å connect the adjacent chains to a 3D supramolecular structures along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 2 

Complex 2 shows a zigzag 1D chain and crystallizes in the monoclinic space group of P21/c. In the asymmetric unit of complex 2, there are one Co(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand and one bpy ligand. The Co(II) atom is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from one chelating bpy ligand ( a). The dpd2- ligand adopts a chelating coordination mode to connect two Co(II) atoms (b), linking the Co(II) atoms into a zigzag 1D chain (c). The π⋯π stacking interactions of the nearly bpy ligands with the distances between 3.7059Å and 3.8962Å connect the adjacent chains to a 3D supramolecular structures along a axis (b).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st095">Crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group. There are one Cu(II) atom, one dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd and one bpy ligand in the asymmetric unit (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). The coordination geometry of Cu(II) atom is completed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one oxygen from one H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd ligand and two nitrogen atoms from one bpy ligand. The Cu–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.9095–1.9576<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Cu–N bond lengths are 1.984 and 2.001<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. One type of dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand is completely deprotonated, exhibiting both chelating and monodentate coordination modes (c). The other type of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd ligand doesn’t deprotonated in order to reach the charge conservation, exhibiting a monodentate coordination mode (d). Adjacent Cu(II) atoms are connected by dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into an infinite 1D chain (b). These chains are further connected by the hydrogen bonding interactions between the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O⋯O distance of 2.6297<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and weak π⋯π stacking interactions existing between phenyl rings of dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (distances of 3.8010–3.9407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) into a 2D supromolecular layer (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 3 

Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/c space group. There are one Cu(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one H2dpd and one bpy ligand in the asymmetric unit ( a). The coordination geometry of Cu(II) atom is completed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligand, one oxygen from one H2dpd ligand and two nitrogen atoms from one bpy ligand. The Cu-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.9095-1.9576Å and Cu-N bond lengths are 1.984 and 2.001Å. One type of dpd2- ligand is completely deprotonated, exhibiting both chelating and monodentate coordination modes (c). The other type of H2dpd ligand doesn't deprotonated in order to reach the charge conservation, exhibiting a monodentate coordination mode (d). Adjacent Cu(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into an infinite 1D chain (b). These chains are further connected by the hydrogen bonding interactions between the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O⋯O distance of 2.6297Å) and weak π⋯π stacking interactions existing between phenyl rings of dpd2- ligands (distances of 3.8010-3.9407Å) into a 2D supromolecular layer (c).

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shows a mononuclear structure, and crystallizes in the triclinic space group of <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

The Mn(II) atom is six-coordinated by two O donors from one dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand with one coordinated water molecule and four N donors from two chelating phen ligands in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a). In <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, only one carboxyl group of the dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand participates in bonding while the other one remains free satisfying the charge of the metal centers, exhibiting another coordination mode (e). There are two chelating phen ligands in each asymmetric unit, which occupy four coordination sites of Mn(II) atom. The chelating phen ligands terminate two possible dimensions, which may prevent the complex forming a higher dimensional network. The monomers self-assemble via hydrogen bonding interactions to form 1D linear chains (b). Theses chains are further connected by π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances between 3.6042–3.8506<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å to lead a 3D supramolucular structure (c).</ce:para>

Crystal structure of 4 

Complex 4 shows a mononuclear structure, and crystallizes in the triclinic space group of   P   1   ¯    . The asymmetric unit contains one Mn(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, two phen ligands and one coordinated water molecule. The Mn(II) atom is six-coordinated by two O donors from one dpd2- ligand with one coordinated water molecule and four N donors from two chelating phen ligands in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry ( a). In 4, only one carboxyl group of the dpd2- ligand participates in bonding while the other one remains free satisfying the charge of the metal centers, exhibiting another coordination mode (e). There are two chelating phen ligands in each asymmetric unit, which occupy four coordination sites of Mn(II) atom. The chelating phen ligands terminate two possible dimensions, which may prevent the complex forming a higher dimensional network. The monomers self-assemble via hydrogen bonding interactions to form 1D linear chains (b). Theses chains are further connected by π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances between 3.6042-3.8506Å to lead a 3D supramolucular structure (c).

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> space group. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>a, there are one Co(II) atoms, one dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. The Co(II) atom in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry formed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand. The Co–O bond lengths range from 2.056–2.244<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Co–N bond lengths are 2.082 and 2.133<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand in complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> adopts the same coordination mode as it in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (c). Adjacent Co(II) atoms are connected by dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into an infinite 1D linear chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.718<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (b). Then, these 1D chains are held together through the hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 2D supramolecular layer (c). Finally, π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5299–3.8667<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å connect the adjacent 2D layer to a 3D supramolecular structure along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (d).</ce:para>

Crystal structure of 5 

Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/n space group. As shown in  a, there are one Co(II) atoms, one dpd2- ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. The Co(II) atom in 5 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry formed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands, one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand. The Co-O bond lengths range from 2.056-2.244Å, and the Co-N bond lengths are 2.082 and 2.133Å. The dpd2- ligand in complex 5 adopts the same coordination mode as it in complex 3 (c). Adjacent Co(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into an infinite 1D linear chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.718Å (b). Then, these 1D chains are held together through the hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 2D supramolecular layer (c). Finally, π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5299-3.8667Å connect the adjacent 2D layer to a 3D supramolecular structure along c axis (d).

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> is a zigzag 1D chain which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2(1)/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group. In the asymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, there are one Co(II) atom, one dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>a). The Co(II) atom is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry by three oxygen atoms from two dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligands and one oxygen atom from one water molecule. In <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand shows the same coordination mode as it in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (c), Co(II) atoms are linked by dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into a zigzag chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.7353<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The phen planes are coordinated with Co(II) atoms in a chelating fashion. The Co–O distances are in the range of 2.058–2.248<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Co–N distances are 2.084 and 2.144<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. In addition, the 1D chains in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are linked together by hydrogen bonding interactions which are caused by the coordinated water molecule into a 2D layer supramolecular structure. Finally, the π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5324–3.8742<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å connect the adjacent 2D layers to a 3D supramolecular structure along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 6 

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 6 is a zigzag 1D chain which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of complex 6, there are one Co(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule ( a). The Co(II) atom is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands, two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligands and one oxygen atom from one water molecule. In 6, dpd2- ligand shows the same coordination mode as it in complex 3 (c), Co(II) atoms are linked by dpd2- ligands into a zigzag chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.7353Å. The phen planes are coordinated with Co(II) atoms in a chelating fashion. The Co-O distances are in the range of 2.058-2.248Å, and the Co-N distances are 2.084 and 2.144Å. In addition, the 1D chains in 6 are linked together by hydrogen bonding interactions which are caused by the coordinated water molecule into a 2D layer supramolecular structure. Finally, the π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5324-3.8742Å connect the adjacent 2D layers to a 3D supramolecular structure along b axis (d).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st115">The effects of the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd ligand and co-ligands on the final structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">According to the descriptions above, we can see that factors such as H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd ligand and auxiliary ligands may influence the final structures of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. There exist five different coordination modes of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> (a–e), which have never been reported before. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the carboxyl groups of dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> adopt bidentate and monodentate-bridging to the Mn(II) atoms, forming a 3D architecture. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> shows a chelating mode and the auxiliary ligand also occupies two coordination sites of Co(II) atom, preventing the 1D structure further forming a higher dimension. In complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> bridges two metal atoms with chelating and monodentate modes, obtaining 1D chain structures. Interestingly, one carboxyl group of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd ligand in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> coordinates with the Cu(II) atom in a monodentate coordination mode without deprotonation in order to reach the charge conservation. In complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the bpy ligand terminates the Mn(II) atoms on each side preventing the coordination among dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and Mn(II) atoms. Thus, the dpd<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand in complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shows a monodentate coordination mode, forming a mononuclear structure. In addition, phen and bpy ligands both show chelating modes in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, which influence the final structures a lot. Supramolecular interactions between the terminal O atoms and auxiliary ligands such as hydrogen bonding and π⋯π stacking interactions benefit the assembly of supramolecular structures of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> with higher dimensions. Thus, both the main and auxiliary ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> may have remarkable effects on the final structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The effects of the H2dpd ligand and co-ligands on the final structures of complexes 1-6 

According to the descriptions above, we can see that factors such as H2dpd ligand and auxiliary ligands may influence the final structures of complexes 1-6. There exist five different coordination modes of H2dpd in 1-6 (a-e), which have never been reported before. In complex 1, the carboxyl groups of dpd2- adopt bidentate and monodentate-bridging to the Mn(II) atoms, forming a 3D architecture. In complex 2, dpd2- shows a chelating mode and the auxiliary ligand also occupies two coordination sites of Co(II) atom, preventing the 1D structure further forming a higher dimension. In complexes 3, 5 and 6, dpd2- bridges two metal atoms with chelating and monodentate modes, obtaining 1D chain structures. Interestingly, one carboxyl group of H2dpd ligand in 3 coordinates with the Cu(II) atom in a monodentate coordination mode without deprotonation in order to reach the charge conservation. In complex 4, the bpy ligand terminates the Mn(II) atoms on each side preventing the coordination among dpd2- and Mn(II) atoms. Thus, the dpd2- ligand in complex 4 shows a monodentate coordination mode, forming a mononuclear structure. In addition, phen and bpy ligands both show chelating modes in 1-6, which influence the final structures a lot. Supramolecular interactions between the terminal O atoms and auxiliary ligands such as hydrogen bonding and π⋯π stacking interactions benefit the assembly of supramolecular structures of 2-6 with higher dimensions. Thus, both the main and auxiliary ligands in 1-6 may have remarkable effects on the final structures.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st120">Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In order to confirm the phase purity of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured at room temperature. As seen in , the peaks of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns are in good agreement with each other, confirming the phase purities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis

In order to confirm the phase purity of complexes 1-6, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured at room temperature. As seen in , the peaks of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns are in good agreement with each other, confirming the phase purities of 1-6.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Then the thermal stabilities of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> have been studied, their thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature of 30–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the weight loss is from 30 to 123<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C which is corresponded to the removal of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.71%, found: 3.45%). The residual framework begins to decompose at 227<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and the retention weight is 14.73% (calculated: 14.62%), corresponding to MnO powder. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> remain stable up to 322<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively, then start to decompose. The remaining weight can be attributed to the formation of Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (calculated: 17.60%, found: 17.55%) and CuO (calculated: 10.85%, found: 11.06%). The TGA curve of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shows a weight loss of 2.91% occurring in the range of 30–120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C corresponding to the removal of one water molecule (calculated: 2.61%). After the loss of the coordinated water molecule, the residue is stable up to 308<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and begins to decompose upon further heating. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of MnO (calculated: 10.29%, found: 10.79%). In the cases of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, weight losses of 4.02% and 3.92% were observed in the temperature ranges of 30–126<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 30–112<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively, corresponding to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.51% and 3.51%, respectively). The residual complexes begin to decompose at 282 and 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C leading to the Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (calculated: 16.15%, found: 15.05%) and Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (calculated: 16.15%, found:16.70%), respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Then the thermal stabilities of complexes 1-6 have been studied, their thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature of 30-600°C (). For complex 1, the weight loss is from 30 to 123°C which is corresponded to the removal of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.71%, found: 3.45%). The residual framework begins to decompose at 227°C and the retention weight is 14.73% (calculated: 14.62%), corresponding to MnO powder. Complex 2 and 3 remain stable up to 322°C and 300°C, respectively, then start to decompose. The remaining weight can be attributed to the formation of Co2O3 (calculated: 17.60%, found: 17.55%) and CuO (calculated: 10.85%, found: 11.06%). The TGA curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 2.91% occurring in the range of 30-120°C corresponding to the removal of one water molecule (calculated: 2.61%). After the loss of the coordinated water molecule, the residue is stable up to 308°C and begins to decompose upon further heating. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of MnO (calculated: 10.29%, found: 10.79%). In the cases of 5 and 6, weight losses of 4.02% and 3.92% were observed in the temperature ranges of 30-126°C and 30-112°C, respectively, corresponding to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.51% and 3.51%, respectively). The residual complexes begin to decompose at 282 and 270°C leading to the Co2O3 (calculated: 16.15%, found: 15.05%) and Co2O3 (calculated: 16.15%, found:16.70%), respectively.

<ce:section-title id="st125">UV–Vis spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The UV–Vis absorption spectra were carried out in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>. The free ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd showed an intense peak ascribed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>–π or π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>–n transition at ca. 257<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . And the broad absorption peaks of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are centered at 250 and 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>); 250, 296 and 536<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); 245, 303 and 660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>); 239, 283 and 397<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>); 237, 270 and 512<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), respectively, which might probably attributed to the intraligand charge–transfer .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis spectra

The UV-Vis absorption spectra were carried out in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in  . The free ligand H2dpd showed an intense peak ascribed to the π∗-π or π∗-n transition at ca. 257nm . And the broad absorption peaks of complexes 1-4 and 6 are centered at 250 and 296nm (for 1); 250, 296 and 536nm (for 2); 245, 303 and 660nm (for 3); 239, 283 and 397nm (for 4); 237, 270 and 512nm (for 6), respectively, which might probably attributed to the intraligand charge-transfer .

<ce:section-title id="st130">Fluorescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">The solid-state emission spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> with free H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd and auxiliary ligands have been investigated at room temperature. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>, the main emission peaks of the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd, bpy and phen ligands are at 361, 390, 379<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), respectively, which may be attributed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>–π or π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>–n transitions of the intraligands . Upon excitation of solid samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, these complexes show emissions bands with maximum at 392<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 386<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 389<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 369<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, 394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> and 390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, respectively. The emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> may be assigned to intraligand transition upon the combination of the mixed ligands with metal ions . The different red shifts and intensities of the emission peaks of these complexes were observed compared with the emission of the free ligands, which may be assigned to the differences of the coordination environment and the different structures because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the coordinated ligands and metal ions . Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> may be good candidates for optical materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence properties

The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-6 with free H2dpd and auxiliary ligands have been investigated at room temperature. As shown in  , the main emission peaks of the H2dpd, bpy and phen ligands are at 361, 390, 379nm (λ ex =250nm), respectively, which may be attributed to the π∗-π or π∗-n transitions of the intraligands . Upon excitation of solid samples of 1-6 at 300nm, these complexes show emissions bands with maximum at 392nm for 1, 386nm for 2, 389nm for 3, 369nm for 4, 394nm for 5 and 390nm for 6, respectively. The emissions of 1-6 may be assigned to intraligand transition upon the combination of the mixed ligands with metal ions . The different red shifts and intensities of the emission peaks of these complexes were observed compared with the emission of the free ligands, which may be assigned to the differences of the coordination environment and the different structures because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the coordinated ligands and metal ions . Complexes 1-6 may be good candidates for optical materials.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

The magnetic behavior of complexes 2-6 have been measured at a temperature range of 2-300K under an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe, which is shown as plots of the product 1/χm  versus T and versus T in    and . The 1/χm  versus T plot for 2 displays Curie-Weiss behavior from 300 to 50K, the best linear fit of χm  -1(T) data above 50K yields C =3.04cm3 Kmol-1 and θ =1.18K. This positive Weiss constant indicates the presence of an ferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) centers through the intermolecular interactions. The χmT value at 300K is 2.78cm3 Kmol-1. Upon cooling the χmT value exhibits a slight increase until 160K; this may be indicative of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions between the Co(II) centers of one-dimensional molecular chains. At low temperature starting from 160K, the χmT value sharply decreases to a minimum value of 1.85cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The magnetic behaviors of complexes 5 and 6 are similar to that of complex 2. The 1/χm  versus T plots for 5 and 6 display Curie-Weiss behaviors from 300 to 50K, the best linear fit of χm  -1(T) data above 50K yields C =3.04cm3 Kmol-1, θ =3.29K for 5 and C =3.04 cm3 Kmol-1, θ =1.18K for 6. This positive Weiss constant indicates the presence of a ferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) centres.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0145" view="all">For complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, however, upon cooling the <ce:italic>χ<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> value exhibits a rapid increase until 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K; this may be indicative of the occurrence of weak ferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) and Mn(II) centers through the intermolecular interactions. As shown in  and , the inverse molar susceptibility above 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K fits well with the Curie–Weiss law with a Curie constant <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5874<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and a Weiss temperature <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>42.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.03<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>θ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.93<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The positive Weiss constant indicated ferromagnetic coupling between the Cu(II) and Mn(II) ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For complexes 3 and 4, however, upon cooling the χmT value exhibits a rapid increase until 10K and 45K; this may be indicative of the occurrence of weak ferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) and Mn(II) centers through the intermolecular interactions. As shown in  and , the inverse molar susceptibility above 50K fits well with the Curie-Weiss law with a Curie constant C =0.5874cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss temperature θ =42.37K for 3 and C =4.03cm3 Kmol-1, θ =6.93K for 4. The positive Weiss constant indicated ferromagnetic coupling between the Cu(II) and Mn(II) ions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st140">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">In conclusion, six metal–organic coordination polymers assembled by H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd and auxiliary ligands have been hydrothermally synthesized and structural characterized. According to the analyses of structures, it seems that the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd and auxiliary ligands play important roles in the constructions of final structures in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. Fluorescent measurements show that the red shifts and intensities of the emission peaks may be assigned to the differences of the coordination environment, indicating that they may be potential applications as optical materials. In addition, complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> all show ferromagnetic behaviors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, six metal-organic coordination polymers assembled by H2dpd and auxiliary ligands have been hydrothermally synthesized and structural characterized. According to the analyses of structures, it seems that the H2dpd and auxiliary ligands play important roles in the constructions of final structures in complexes 1-6. Fluorescent measurements show that the red shifts and intensities of the emission peaks may be assigned to the differences of the coordination environment, indicating that they may be potential applications as optical materials. In addition, complexes 2-6 all show ferromagnetic behaviors.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">A mixture of Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0490<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>dpd (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0512<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), bpy (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0312<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 25% (C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NOH (mass fraction) aqueous solution (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After cooling to room temperature at a speed of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, yellow crystals of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained, washed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air (Yield: 42% based on Mn). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>MnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>: C, 59.39; H, 3.74, N, 5.77. Found: C, 59.29; H, 3.88; N, 5.72%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3381 (s), 1590 (s), 1545 (s), 1479 (m), 1422(s), 1365 (m), 1243 (s), 1165 (m), 1102 (w), 1057 (w), 1032 (m), 1006 (w), 893 (m), 847 (m), 802 (w), 759 (s), 720 (w), 645 (w), 612 (w), 497(w).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st045">Synthesis of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The synthetic procedure was similar to that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, except Co(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0498<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) replaced Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The dark red crystals were obtained, washed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air (Yield: 65% based on Co). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>: C, 61.16; H, 3.42; N, 5.94. Found: C, 61.06; H, 3.37; N, 5.85%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3381 (s), 1596 (s), 1551 (s), 1476 (m), 1440 (m), 1395(s), 1372 (s), 1221 (s), 1161 (m), 1092 (m), 1049 (s), 877 (m), 759 (s), 709 (w), 697 (w), 669 (w), 646 (m), 559 (w), 535 (w), 465 (w).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st050">Synthesis of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The synthetic procedure was similar to that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, except Cu(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0398<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) replaced Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The blue crystals were obtained, washed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air (Yield: 33% based on Cu). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">25</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>: C, 62.25; H, 3.44; N, 3.82. Found: C, 62.34; H, 3.57; N, 3.75%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3381 (s), 1598 (s), 1540 (s), 1473 (m), 1443 (s), 1416(s), 1315 (m), 1239 (s), 1159 (m), 1095 (m), 1056 (w), 1024 (w), 1013 (w), 887 (m), 855 (m), 806 (w), 774 (s), 765 (s), 735 (w), 714 (w), 666 (w), 649 (w), 606 (w), 510 (w).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st055">Synthesis of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The synthetic procedure was similar to that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, except the temperature was adjusted to 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and bpy was replaced by phen (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g). The yellow crystals were obtained, washed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air (Yield: 45% based on Mn). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>MnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>: C, 66.19; H, 3.80; N, 8.12. Found: C, 66.25; H, 3.62; N, 8.15%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3381 (s), 1619 (s), 1593 (s), 1572 (m), 1562 (m), 1552 (m), 1514 (m), 1478 (w), 1444 (w), 1425 (m), 1370 (s), 1230 (s), 1153 (w), 1092 (w), 1040 (w), 881 (w), 863 (w), 847 (m), 809 (w), 757 (w), 728 (m), 669 (w), 544 (w), 506 (w), 493 (w), 455 (w), 440 (w).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st060">Synthesis of complex <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The synthetic procedure was similar to that of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, except Co(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.0498<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) replaced Mn(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The orange block crystals were obtained, washed with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and dried in air (Yield: 58% based on Co). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>: C, 60.83; H, 3.53; N, 5.46. Found: C, 60.72; H, 3.59; N, 5.56%. Synthesis of complex 1 

A mixture of Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.2mmol, 0.0490g), H2dpd (0.2mmol, 0.0512g), bpy (0.2mmol, 0.0312g), 25% (C2H5)4NOH (mass fraction) aqueous solution (0.1ml) and H2O (5mL) was sealed in a 23mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated to 160°C for 3days. After cooling to room temperature at a speed of 10°C/h, yellow crystals of complex 1 were obtained, washed with H2O and dried in air (Yield: 42% based on Mn). Anal. cln_elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of 3 

Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/c space group. There are one Cu(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one H2dpd and one bpy ligand in the asymmetric unit ( a). The coordination geometry of Cu(II) atom is completed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligand, one oxygen from one H2dpd ligand and two nitrogen atoms from one bpy ligand. The Cu-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.9095-1.9576Å and Cu-N bond lengths are 1.984 and 2.001Å. One type of dpd2- ligand is completely deprotonated, exhibiting both chelating and monodentate coordination modes (c). The other type of H2dpd ligand doesn't deprotonated in order to reach the charge conservation, exhibiting a monodentate coordination mode (d). Adjacent Cu(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into an infinite 1D chain (b). These chains are further connected by the hydrogen bonding interactions between the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O⋯O distance of 2.6297Å) and weak π⋯π stacking interactions existing between phenyl rings of dpd2- ligands (distances of 3.8010-3.9407Å) into a 2D supromolecular layer (c).

Crystal structure of 5 

Single crystal structure analysis reveals that complex 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/n space group. As shown in  a, there are one Co(II) atoms, one dpd2- ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule in the asymmetric unit. The Co(II) atom in 5 adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry formed by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands, one oxygen atom from coordinated water molecule and two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligand. The Co-O bond lengths range from 2.056-2.244Å, and the Co-N bond lengths are 2.082 and 2.133Å. The dpd2- ligand in complex 5 adopts the same coordination mode as it in complex 3 (c). Adjacent Co(II) atoms are connected by dpd2- ligands into an infinite 1D linear chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.718Å (b). Then, these 1D chains are held together through the hydrogen bonding interactions to form a 2D supramolecular layer (c). Finally, π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5299-3.8667Å connect the adjacent 2D layer to a 3D supramolecular structure along c axis (d).

Crystal structure of 6 

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 6 is a zigzag 1D chain which crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system with P2(1)/c space group. In the asymmetric unit of complex 6, there are one Co(II) atom, one dpd2- ligand, one phen ligand and one coordinated water molecule ( a). The Co(II) atom is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry by three oxygen atoms from two dpd2- ligands, two nitrogen atoms from one phen ligands and one oxygen atom from one water molecule. In 6, dpd2- ligand shows the same coordination mode as it in complex 3 (c), Co(II) atoms are linked by dpd2- ligands into a zigzag chain with a Co⋯Co distance of 11.7353Å. The phen planes are coordinated with Co(II) atoms in a chelating fashion. The Co-O distances are in the range of 2.058-2.248Å, and the Co-N distances are 2.084 and 2.144Å. In addition, the 1D chains in 6 are linked together by hydrogen bonding interactions which are caused by the coordinated water molecule into a 2D layer supramolecular structure. Finally, the π⋯π stacking interactions between the nearby phen ligands with the distances of 3.5324-3.8742Å connect the adjacent 2D layers to a 3D supramolecular structure along b axis (d).

Then the thermal stabilities of complexes 1-6 have been studied, their thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed in the temperature of 30-600°C (). For complex 1, the weight loss is from 30 to 123°C which is corresponded to the removal of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.71%, found: 3.45%). The residual framework begins to decompose at 227°C and the retention weight is 14.73% (calculated: 14.62%), corresponding to MnO powder. Complex 2 and 3 remain stable up to 322°C and 300°C, respectively, then start to decompose. The remaining weight can be attributed to the formation of Co2O3 (calculated: 17.60%, found: 17.55%) and CuO (calculated: 10.85%, found: 11.06%). The TGA curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 2.91% occurring in the range of 30-120°C corresponding to the removal of one water molecule (calculated: 2.61%). After the loss of the coordinated water molecule, the residue is stable up to 308°C and begins to decompose upon further heating. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of MnO (calculated: 10.29%, found: 10.79%). In the cases of 5 and 6, weight losses of 4.02% and 3.92% were observed in the temperature ranges of 30-126°C and 30-112°C, respectively, corresponding to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calculated: 3.51% and 3.51%, respectively). The residual complexes begin to decompose at 282 and 270°C leading to the Co2O3 (calculated: 16.15%, found: 15.05%) and Co2O3 (calculated: 16.15%, found:16.70%), respectively.

UV-Vis spectra

The UV-Vis absorption spectra were carried out in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in  . The free ligand H2dpd showed an intense peak ascribed to the π∗-π or π∗-n transition at ca. 257nm . And the broad absorption peaks of complexes 1-4 and 6 are centered at 250 and 296nm (for 1); 250, 296 and 536nm (for 2); 245, 303 and 660nm (for 3); 239, 283 and 397nm (for 4); 237, 270 and 512nm (for 6), respectively, which might probably attributed to the intraligand charge-transfer .

Fluorescence properties

The solid-state emission spectra of complexes 1-6 with free H2dpd and auxiliary ligands have been investigated at room temperature. As shown in  , the main emission peaks of the H2dpd, bpy and phen ligands are at 361, 390, 379nm (λ ex =250nm), respectively, which may be attributed to the π∗-π or π∗-n transitions of the intraligands . Upon excitation of solid samples of 1-6 at 300nm, these complexes show emissions bands with maximum at 392nm for 1, 386nm for 2, 389nm for 3, 369nm for 4, 394nm for 5 and 390nm for 6, respectively. The emissions of 1-6 may be assigned to intraligand transition upon the combination of the mixed ligands with metal ions . The different red shifts and intensities of the emission peaks of these complexes were observed compared with the emission of the free ligands, which may be assigned to the differences of the coordination environment and the different structures because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the coordinated ligands and metal ions . Complexes 1-6 may be good candidates for optical materials.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

The magnetic behavior of complexes 2-6 have been measured at a temperature range of 2-300K under an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe, which is shown as plots of the product 1/χm  versus T and versus T in    and . The 1/χm  versus T plot for 2 displays Curie-Weiss behavior from 300 to 50K, the best linear fit of χm  -1(T) data above 50K yields C =3.04cm3 Kmol-1 and θ =1.18K. This positive Weiss constant indicates the presence of an ferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) centers through the intermolecular interactions. The χmT value at 300K is 2.78cm3 Kmol-1. Upon cooling the χmT value exhibits a slight increase until 160K; this may be indicative of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions between the Co(II) centers of one-dimensional molecular chains. At low temperature starting from 160K, the χmT value sharply decreases to a minimum value of 1.85cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The magnetic behaviors of complexes 5 and 6 are similar to that of complex 2. The 1/χm  versus T plots for 5 and 6 display Curie-Weiss behaviors from 300 to 50K, the best linear fit of χm  -1(T) data above 50K yields C =3.04cm3 Kmol-1, θ =3.29K for 5 and C =3.04 cm3 Kmol-1, θ =1.18K for 6. This positive Weiss constant indicates the presence of a ferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) centres.

For complexes 3 and 4, however, upon cooling the χmT value exhibits a rapid increase until 10K and 45K; this may be indicative of the occurrence of weak ferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) and Mn(II) centers through the intermolecular interactions. As shown in  and , the inverse molar susceptibility above 50K fits well with the Curie-Weiss law with a Curie constant C =0.5874cm3 Kmol-1 and a Weiss temperature θ =42.37K for 3 and C =4.03cm3 Kmol-1, θ =6.93K for 4. The positive Weiss constant indicated ferromagnetic coupling between the Cu(II) and Mn(II) ions.
